Award.AwardTitle: Explicit Approaches to Elliptic Curves, Modular Forms and Modular Abelian Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The projects in this proposal would generalize the highly
influential tables of Cremona to the next (ordered by discriminant) totally real
number field and to higher dimensional modular abelian varieties. This would
improve on algorithms available for computing with elliptic curves and abelian
varieties, and provide useful data and tools for number theory researchers. The
proposed research would also advance techniques for constructing points and coho-
mology classes on elliptic curves, and for understanding the arithmetic of elliptic
curves over number fields. This project would have as a concrete deliverable new
publicly available tables and software that will be of use to many number theorists.

Broader Impact: The PI is co-authoring a popular expository book with Barry
Mazur on the Riemann Hypothesis, co-authoring a graduate level book with Ken-
neth Ribet on modular forms and Hecke operators, and intends to release a new
edition of his modular forms book. The PI has tables of data that are freely avail-
able online, and whose creation has been supported by NSF FRG grant DMS-
0757627, and the proposed research would expand these tables further. He will
also continue to organize the development of the free open source NSF-funded
Sage mathematical software project that he started. The PI organizes dozens of
"Sage Days" workshops that involve many undergraduate and graduate students,
and touch on number theory, algebraic topology, combinatorics, special functions,
numerical computation, and other areas. The PI is also a co-PI on the UTMOST
NSF grant (DUE-1020378), whose goal is to make Sage more accessible to high
school and college teachers and students.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Washington, Dept of Math

POR.DRECONTENT:
Simon Spicer: During each of my two summers supported by this NSF grant (2012 and 2013), my time was split between learning the necessary mathematics in order to work on implementing the elliptic curve-related methods for L-series and curve enumeration, then writing said code for Sage. I also wrote up the accompanying mathematical analysis for publication in my Ph.D. dissertation (published 2015).


Hao Chen: I spent my time exploring various approaches to constructing distinguished rational divisors on modular curves and studying their image on elliptic curves, via the modular parametrization. I also studied Chow-Heegner points, and completely proved a new result (conjectured by the PI, Stein) that the index is always even.


Alyson Deines: I helped create tables of elliptic curves over Q(sqrt(5)) and also worked with the LMFDB project to make the tables easily searchable and widely available.  I developed techniques for understanding discriminants of elliptic curves over the rational numbers and number fields in my 2014 Ph.D. thesis.


R. Andrew Ohana: I rewrote and modified large parts of Sage's build system to handle the restructuring of Sage's directory structure. I also added a large Sage-specific Trac plugin to handle our development needs.  I also revamped the Sage computer infrastructure during two weeks while funded by this grant.
Travis Scholl: I worked extensively on a graduate-level textbook book on Algebraic number theory, under contract to publish with the American Mathematical Society.


William Stein: I assisted with all of the above mentioned projects. Also, did collaborative research with Barry Mazur related to modular symbols and elliptic curves, and finished a book on the Riemann Hypothesis (co-authored with Barry Mazur), which will be published with Cambridge University Press in early 2016.  I also worked on co-authoring graduate text on algebraic number theory.  I worked on paper on elliptic curve average ranks with Jen Balakrishnan and Simon Spicer, which will be submitted soon.  I had several papers on p-adic BSD for abelian varieties accepted.


Last Modified: 09/27/2015
Modified by: William A Stein
